metadata.synopsis: Halsin, arch-druid of the Emerald Grove, is  freed from the goblins and changes back from bear form, thanking the players. They can ask him about their tadpole problem, but he wants help saving the grove first - either by killing the goblin leadership or defending the grove, whichever is applicable. The player can insist on learning what they can from him to help with their tadpole, if they wish.
metadata.how_to_trigger:
goto 393; -45

roll amazingWalk toward the cage on the top rightIn the dialogue -  Choices : 1 - 4

Choose to attack the goblins and kill them.Talk to Halsin after the combat in wolf pens in the goblin camp.

35.speaker: Halsin
35.text: Where are you going? We have work to do - enemies to kill.

121.speaker: Player
121.text: Of course. Let's focus on that.

68.speaker: Player
68.text: This will have to wait for now.

195.speaker: Halsin
195.text: I'll wait here. Just know that you're gambling with the grove's very existence.

303.speaker: Player
303.text: The other leaders are dead, but Minthara has left for the grove.

72.speaker: Halsin
72.text: Nature's blessings. Are you ready to do what is necessary?

254.speaker: Player
254.text: Tell me what you know about Moonrise Towers.

96.speaker: Halsin
96.text: The grove is counting on us.

128.speaker: Halsin
128.text: The ringleaders have to die. The very natural order of things is in danger, thanks to them.

11.speaker: Player
11.text: Come with me. I could use your help.

172.speaker: Halsin
172.text: Very well. My claws are yours.

106.speaker: Player
106.text: All the leaders are dead - the grove's safe.

192.speaker: Halsin
192.text: You did it. You actually did it! The leaders dead - praise Silvanus.
192.context: InternalNodeContext: Disable his dialogue, he then disappears, appears in the Grove and gets a new dialogueNodeContext: Jubilant. The leaders of the horde threatening his home have been eliminated.

101.speaker: Halsin
101.text: No, that's not right - praise you, my friend. The grove owes you a debt beyond measure.

41.speaker: Halsin
41.text: Killing's never my first choice, but those three were too dangerous to leave alive.

115.speaker: Player
115.text: Thank me not, the slaughter was a pleasure.

119.speaker: Halsin
119.text: You sound all but deranged by blood, but I suppose even a feral wolf has a caring hound at heart.

107.speaker: Player
107.text: I've done my part - now tell me about Moonrise.

308.speaker: Halsin
308.text: Let's get out of this pit, firstly.

244.speaker: Halsin
244.text: I have some matters to settle, then I'll join you at your camp. There, we can talk properly.

198.speaker: Halsin
198.text: Return to the grove; I'll make my own way there.

304.speaker: Halsin
304.text: And you'll receive it. I'll make my way to your camp, as soon as I've settled some matters.

56.speaker: Halsin
56.text: And you'll receive it soon enough. Return to the grove; I'll make my own way there.

273.speaker: Halsin
273.text: Not so hasty, friend. With the goblins' leaders dead, I can help you. I'll come to your camp, once I've settled some matters.

125.speaker: Halsin
125.text: I'll make my way to the grove - join me there.

260.speaker: Halsin
260.text: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
260.context: InternalNodeContext: Intro happens only once, that's why Global FlagNodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.

147.speaker: Halsin
147.text: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.

16.speaker: Halsin
16.text: You aided a bear without knowing if it would savage you? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.

124.speaker: Halsin
124.text: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.

52.speaker: Player
52.text: Glad I could be of help.

287.speaker: Halsin
287.text: I must admit, I didn't expect anyone would come to my aid. Who in their right mind would infiltrate a goblin infested temple. Unless...

318.speaker: Player
318.text: You're Halsin? The Master Halsin of the Emerald Grove?

274.speaker: Halsin
274.text: Yes, but just Halsin will suffice. Unbecoming to demand honorifics from the one who saved my hide.

54.speaker: Halsin
54.text: Well, consider me introduced. And consider me grateful.

130.speaker: Player
130.text: I spoke to Nettie - she said you could help me with the parasite in my head.

141.speaker: Halsin
141.text: Parasite in your head...? You mean you have one of them?

161.speaker: Player
161.text: I've heard you're an unmatched healer. I need your help.

142.speaker: Player
142.text: Impressive healing skills. I need the help of someone like you.
142.context: InternalNodeContext: Halsin cast a healing spell on himself before this dialogue bagan, If the player doesn't know who he is, this is the reasoning for them asking him to help them.

134.speaker: Halsin
134.text: Indeed? Not the most opportune moment, but given the lengths you went to, I assume there's some urgency.

138.speaker: Halsin
138.text: Come on then, what's the problem? Unless you'd rather wait for an audience of goblins.

79.speaker: Player
79.text: I've been to the Emerald Grove. It's in danger.

252.speaker: Halsin
252.text: I am aware. I foolishly left it vulnerable to this rabble. There's work to be done.
252.context: NodeContext: This rabble - the goblins etc.

28.speaker: Player
28.text: You should get out of here. It's not safe.

196.speaker: Halsin
196.text: Oh, I'm quite aware of that, rest assured - but where is safe right now?

77.speaker: Halsin
77.text: ...Hrrm. That look in your eyes - I've seen it before. Are you feeling all right?
77.context: NodeContext: switching subject, realizing there is something wrong with you

180.context: CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you

243.speaker: Halsin
243.text: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.

280.speaker: Halsin
280.text: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
280.context: NodeContext: The player's in dire straits, but Halsin can't help but be a little fascinated by their condition, Professional interest,

133.speaker: Player
133.text: I escaped from an illithid ship after being infected. Maybe the process was interrupted.

95.speaker: Halsin
95.text: Perhaps... but I wouldn't want to place all my faith in blind luck.

202.speaker: Player
202.text: I think this artefact has something to do with it.

63.speaker: Halsin
63.text: Hmmm... that looks very alien. As alien as the mind flayers. They do not belong on this world.

245.speaker: Halsin
245.text: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.

285.speaker: Halsin
285.text: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.

92.speaker: Halsin
92.text: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.

268.speaker: Halsin
268.text: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.

80.speaker: Halsin
80.text: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.

232.speaker: Halsin
232.text: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.

292.speaker: Player
292.text: Tell me what you've learned about the tadpoles' origins.

94.speaker: Halsin
94.text: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.

37.speaker: Halsin
37.text: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.

222.speaker: Halsin
222.text: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.

81.speaker: Player
81.text: You seem to know a lot about this. Will you come with me to Moonrise?

219.speaker: Halsin
219.text: Gladly, but I have some matters to settle first. You go ahead - I'll join you at your camp.

111.speaker: Halsin
111.text: Gladly, but first I must return to the grove. As you made short work of the goblins' leaders, there's nothing stopping me. Come join me in your own time.

167.speaker: Halsin
167.text: I can see to some matters there, and we can discuss what comes next amidst more... bucolic surroundings than here.
167.context: NodeContext: Halsin would very much like to leave the grim dungeon and go back to his grove.

301.speaker: Halsin
301.text: I wish I could, but there's still work I've yet to finish - blood I've yet to spill.

208.speaker: Halsin
208.text: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
208.context: NodeContext: A touch sheepish. We've just freed him, and now he finds he has to ask another favour.

1.speaker: Halsin
1.text: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
1.context: NodeContext: Practical. No lover of violence, but knows when needs must. Gestures at the surrounds on 'these butchers' to refer to the goblins and their allies.

178.speaker: Player
178.text: All right. How do I help?

158.speaker: Halsin
158.text: My thanks. If you prevail, I'll owe you the debt of a lifetime.

297.speaker: Halsin
297.text: It's too late to stop things from here - the goblins are already marching on the grove in force.

227.speaker: Halsin
227.text: You must get ahead of them, muster the defences.

186.speaker: Player
186.text: Very well. I'll go rescue the grove.

55.speaker: Halsin
55.text: Thank you. I know it's a great deal to ask, but the grove is everything to me.

45.speaker: Halsin
45.text: Hurry, then. I will meet you there.

288.speaker: Player
288.text: You ask too much of me. I can't help you.

15.speaker: Halsin
15.text: Then the grove is doomed, and perhaps you as well.

93.speaker: Halsin
93.text: I'll pray to Silvanus that you have a change of heart. But time is short.

151.speaker: Player
151.text: At least tell me what you know about Moonrise. You owe me, after all.

0.speaker: Halsin
0.text: As you wish. Better I impart the knowledge to you now, in case I fall trying to defend the grove.

190.speaker: Player
190.text: I'm not much of a hero... those I look after seem to end up dead.

300.speaker: Halsin
300.text: Death is nature's final slumber - it awaits us all. Do not punish yourself over those lost, or give in to despair - not while there are still folk in need of your help.

71.speaker: Halsin
71.text: Rare is the beast that survives decapitation. Help me eliminate the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut.
71.context: NodeContext: Giving a list of targets in exchange for his help. D-Roar Rags-lin, Min-Thara

7.speaker: Player
7.text: Look around you - there's no order anymore. Only chaos.

290.speaker: Halsin
290.text: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
290.context: NodeContext: Emphatic. A matter of great importance for him,

69.speaker: Halsin
69.text: It's too late to merely kill this horde's leadership - their forces are already marching. If you want me to help, you need to help me first.

113.speaker: Halsin
113.text: Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.
113.context: NodeContext: Practical. No lover of violence, but knows when needs must.

266.speaker: Halsin
266.text: Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut.

168.speaker: Halsin
168.text: They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
168.context: NodeContext: Practical. No lover of violence, but knows when needs must.

233.speaker: Player
233.text: Doubtful - I already killed the goblin leadership.

14.speaker: Halsin
14.text: You did...? Nature's found a most furious defender in you.
14.context: NodeContext: Surprised and impressed. The player has fulfilled a mission before he could issue it.

118.speaker: Halsin
118.text: Very well. Return to the grove. I'll make my own way there - then we can see about this parasite of yours.

225.speaker: Player
225.text: Having a shapeshifting bear-druid at my side might make things easier.

270.speaker: Player
270.text: I'll deal with this. You get to safety.

144.speaker: Halsin
144.text: I told you, nowhere is safe. Not while this rot festers. Once it is cut out - once the grove is secure - then I shall leave.

44.speaker: Halsin
44.text: There is no safety. Not while this rot festers. Once it is cut out - once the grove is secure - then I shall leave.

70.speaker: Player
70.text: Follow me, then. Your bear form may prove useful.

26.speaker: Halsin
26.text: Be warned - my presence could make things more difficult... I can only restrain my bear form so much. I won't be able to help but attack goblins.
26.context: NodeContext: A warning of sorts - he doesn't want to be a liability.

25.speaker: Halsin
25.text: If I join you, we'll likely have to slaughter this entire place. You may want to use discretion when approaching the goblin leaders.
25.context: NodeContext: A warning of sorts - he doesn't want to be a liability.

295.speaker: Halsin
295.text: So be it. May Silvanus lend us nature's fury.
295.context: NodeContext: Great resolve. Ready to march into battle.

271.speaker: Player
271.text: All right. Wait here until it's done.

217.speaker: Halsin
217.text: May Silvanus guide your hand. Focus on the leaders - that's all it will take to restore the balance here.

309.speaker: Player
309.text: You are aware you're asking me to kill a drow?

212.speaker: Halsin
212.text: You drow relish turning on your own, if there's something to be gained. Don't pretend otherwise.
212.context: NodeContext: Speaking to a drow - 'please, don't pretend to be a bleeding heart' (prejudiced, but a common and often correct assessment of drow)

21.speaker: Player
21.text: Not all drow are as you say.

39.speaker: Halsin
39.text: Unfair of me, perhaps, but I've had few encounters with drow to make me think otherwise.
39.context: NodeContext: 'Prove me wrong. Save the innocents at the grove'

62.speaker: Halsin
62.context: NodeContext: 'Prove me wrong. Save the innocents at the grove'

240.speaker: Player
240.text: The grove isn't my problem. I have to concentrate on saving myself.

182.speaker: Halsin
182.text: I understand. You've done far more than most have for the grove, just by freeing me.
182.context: NodeContext: Stiff upper lip. He's crushed that the player won't help, but he maintains dignity

120.speaker: Halsin
120.text: I cannot come with you, though I wish I could. At least let me tell you what I know; help you on your journey.

129.speaker: Halsin
129.text: Travelling to Moonrise is no small task. Expect dangers like you've never seen before.

201.speaker: Player
201.text: I'm something of an expert when it comes to imperilling myself.

48.speaker: Halsin
48.text: This is different. There's more fingers on a hand than there are survivors of that place.
48.context: NodeContext: Deadly serious and speaking from personal experience, The place he's talking about is no joke.

307.speaker: Player
307.text: I think you're exaggerating. You just want me to stay and help you.

131.speaker: Halsin
131.text: I do want you to help me, yes. But I am not exaggerating.

173.speaker: Halsin
173.text: To get to the Towers, you'll need to pass through a terrible place - a cursed place.

154.speaker: Halsin
154.text: This curse shrouds everything in shadow - you will not find life, light, or anything natural there.

149.speaker: Halsin
149.text: Any who linger are twisted by the curse; they become shadow beings - tormented, dangerous souls.

220.speaker: Player
220.text: Sounds like I've no choice - I need to find a way through.

293.speaker: Halsin
293.text: You're half right - you have to get to Moonrise, but you still have a choice of how to get there.

163.speaker: Player
163.text: The Absolute's forces can tolerate such a place?

122.speaker: Halsin
122.text: So it seems, though I don't know how. You will have to choose your approach carefully.

194.speaker: Player
194.text: There must be another way to cure myself.

17.speaker: Halsin
17.text: By all means - pursue any leads you may have. But I sense all roads will lead to Moonrise.

209.speaker: Halsin
209.text: You could go overland - along the Risen Road or through the mountains. Easier at first, but you'll run into the shadow curse eventually.

98.speaker: Halsin
98.text: You could also go under. There is a tunnel somewhere in this very temple of Selûne. It leads to Moonrise Towers through the Underdark.

112.speaker: Halsin
112.text: Long ago, a man called Ketheric Thorm built a secret stronghold deep down there, before rallying a whole army of Dark Justiciars - Shar worshippers.

230.speaker: Shadowheart
230.text: Dark Justiciars? I must see for myself.

9.speaker: Halsin
9.text: Aradin and his lot were looking for a way down there - they were promised riches if they retrieved a relic called the Nightsong. But I think there's more.

18.speaker: Halsin
18.text: From this stronghold, Ketheric's forces could access both the temple of Selûne and Moonrise Towers - but he was defeated before he could launch an attack.

312.speaker: Halsin
312.text: If you can find this place, I'll wager it will reveal a more direct path to Moonrise Towers, and may bypass the worst of the shadow curse.

275.speaker: Player
275.text: I already found the place you're talking about - it's called Grymforge.
275.context: InternalNodeContext: This QN if the player has already entered the grymforge but has not yet spoken to Halsin about it.

165.speaker: Halsin
165.text: You've already been? Impressive. You'll make me redundant at this rate. What did you find?
165.context: NodeContext: Impressed and a little amused at the player's diligence (finding a place before he can even tell them about it)

74.speaker: Player
74.text: I found an elevator - but it leads right into the shadow curse.
74.context: InternalNodeContext: This node if the player clicked the elevator from Grymforge to SCL

148.speaker: Halsin
148.text: That sounds like what you need. But the next part of the journey mightn't be straightforward - or safe.

183.speaker: Player
183.text: Absolute followers - but that's about all.
183.context: InternalNodeContext: This node if the player didn't click the elevator from Grymforge to SCL

177.speaker: Halsin
177.text: Keep looking. If they're present, then it's likely there's a route to Moonrise somewhere.

160.speaker: Player
160.text: Danger. Are you sure that's the best way to Moonrise?

36.speaker: Halsin
36.text: I'm certain. The Underdark is dangerous, yes, but the alternative is suicide. Be patient and be thorough - the path will reveal itself in time.

102.speaker: Halsin
102.text: It may prove impossible to avoid the shadow curse entirely, but if you find any way to limit your exposure, seize it.
102.context: InternalNodeContext: GLO_Halsin_AcknowledgedGrymforge sets whenever the player enquires about the Grymforge and Halsin acknowledges how it may relate to the journey to Moonrise.

310.speaker: Player
310.text: I've got more exploring to do.

65.speaker: Halsin
65.text: Tread carefully. You're on the right track, I'm sure - but there'll still be danger and difficulty before you reach Moonrise.

10.speaker: Player
10.text: I found the hidden entrance in the temple of Selûne - the way is clear.

38.speaker: Halsin
38.text: Already...? If only I'd gone with you instead of Aradin.

298.speaker: Player
298.text: I've already found a way into the Underdark. I can pick up the trail from there.

67.speaker: Player
67.text: So how do I find this underground route?

187.speaker: Halsin
187.text: You'll need to pick up where Aradin left off - find the hidden entrance. It's somewhere in these ruins, from what I've heard.

283.speaker: Halsin
283.text: One of the adventurers had a clue to help find it - a dwarf called Brian. It might still be found on his corpse, wherever the goblins left it.

279.speaker: Player
279.text: I don't want to risk getting lost in the Underdark - I'll journey overland.

143.speaker: Halsin
143.text: You may reconsider once you see the effects of the curse for yourself.

137.speaker: Player
137.text: How do I find this passage through the Underdark?

53.speaker: Player
53.text: Say I decide to try this Underdark route after all - how do I get started?

157.speaker: Player
157.text: What business do you have at Moonrise? You said you'd go there, if you could.

223.speaker: Halsin
223.text: My business there began long ago, and has led to a lifetime of regret.

34.speaker: Halsin
34.text: I helped overthrow Ketheric Thorm and his Dark Justiciars years ago. But I failed to prevent him from unleashing darkness across the region before he was defeated.

251.speaker: Halsin
251.text: I spent years researching the curse, trying to put an end to it. Nothing has worked - yet.

228.speaker: Halsin
228.text: If I could join you and get close to Moonrise, perhaps I could have both helped you find a cure for your infection and lifted the curse.

13.speaker: Halsin
13.text: But the grove must come first, I'm afraid.

218.speaker: Player
218.text: Is that why you went with Aradin? You thought he might uncover this route to Moonrise?

43.speaker: Halsin
43.text: Precisely. Then perhaps I could have done something about both the shadow curse and ceremorphosis aberrations.

181.speaker: Halsin
181.text: But in my eagerness, I put far too much faith in the abilities of Aradin and his band. We didn't even get close.

276.speaker: Halsin
276.text: One of those who died had a clue that was supposed to help us find the hidden entrance to the Underdark.

159.speaker: Halsin
159.text: A dwarf called Brian, I believe. Though there's no guarantee that the goblins left him recognisable.

313.speaker: Player
313.text: I may live to regret this - or maybe I won't - but fine, I'll help you save the grove first.

176.speaker: Halsin
176.text: You will? Oak Father bless you. I'll be in your debt twice over if we succeed.

263.speaker: Halsin
263.text: Now, there's no time to lose - get to the grove and help with the defences.

174.speaker: Halsin
174.text: You know what's needed - the deaths of Dror Ragzlin, the drow Minthara, and the priestess, Gut. May nature guide you.

8.speaker: Halsin
8.text: I could come and help you... but be warned - I won't be able to suppress my animal side. Subtlety will not be an option.

32.speaker: Player
32.text: I'm sorry I can't do more. Thank you, and good luck with the grove.

20.speaker: Halsin
20.text: I'll need that luck, along with all the Oak Father's blessings.

127.speaker: Halsin
127.text: It seems the Absolute's forces are already marching on the grove. I'll have to try get ahead of them, do what I can.

289.speaker: Halsin
289.text: Farewell. I don't expect we'll meet again - at least not in this life.

12.speaker: Halsin
12.text: I'll remain here and do what I can to disrupt these cultists' plans. Perhaps I can stop their attack before it's even launched. Farewell.

24.speaker: Player
24.text: We're done here. I'll be on my way.

86.speaker: Player
86.text: I never thought I'd say this, but it sounds like the Underdark is the safer route.

205.speaker: Halsin
205.text: Anything is preferable to risking the shadow curse.

40.speaker: Player
40.text: I know the Underdark - it's lethal. I'll travel overland.

238.speaker: Player
238.text: The Underdark's my home. Better to take that route than risk this curse.

306.speaker: Halsin
306.text: The decision is yours, but I'd favour the Underdark. Even a place like that is the lesser evil compared to the shadow-cursed lands.

221.speaker: Player
221.text: This shadow curse - does it affect Shar worshippers?

203.speaker: Halsin
203.text: I don't know. Ketheric's followers were defeated or vanished before the effects of the curse took hold.

234.speaker: Player
234.text: Are these Sharrans still to be found?

248.speaker: Halsin
248.text: As bones, perhaps. But their hidden structures might still remain.

237.speaker: Player
237.text: How are you so sure Moonrise is where I have to go?

139.speaker: Halsin
139.text: Nature speaks to me. Birds report what they've seen. And I've overheard goblins speaking of it, too. Moonrise is at the heart of all this, I'm sure of it.

126.speaker: Player
126.text: Don't make it sound so tempting. I already know you'd rather I stayed and helped you.

247.speaker: Halsin
247.text: That's true, I won't lie. But I won't let you march towards Moonrise without knowing what you'd face.

179.speaker: Player
179.text: Tell me, then. I'm going to do whatever it takes.

256.speaker: Player
256.text: True, but I mustn't be seen spilling drow blood. Stay here - I'll kill the trio quietly.

84.speaker: Player
84.text: Very well, but no witnesses can survive. We will kill this whole camp together.

207.speaker: Player
207.text: There's no pretence in not wanting to play the assassin. You're on your own.

6.speaker: Player
6.text: Best if I try settle this discreetly - wait here, and you'll have your deaths.

259.speaker: Player
259.text: Kagha was swayed by Shadow Druids. She nearly sealed the grove.

193.speaker: Halsin
193.text: Kagha... I should have suspected she'd take things too far. I'll deal with her when I can.
193.context: NodeContext: Displeased yet not entirely surprised. He's going to read Kagha the riot act if he lives long enough to do so.

188.speaker: Halsin
188.text: But there are other matters to attend to before that.

213.speaker: Player
213.text: Kagha is dead. She was swayed by Shadow Druids. I had no choice.

315.speaker: Halsin
315.text: Kagha... This is my fault - I was her teacher. I will mourn her when I can.
315.context: NodeContext: Processing the loss of his understudy, yet he knows she was in the wrong.  He bears no ill will to the player and doesn't have time to truly mourn while his mission is still ongoing

4.speaker: Player
4.text: The other druids are dead, by my hand.

132.speaker: Halsin
132.text: What...? How? Why?! Explain yourself at once!

89.speaker: Player
89.text: They left me no choice. I had to defend myself.

239.speaker: Halsin
239.text: Then... then it is as you say. They forgot their principles; you had no choice. I will mourn them when I can.
239.context: NodeContext: Processing the loss of his comrades, yet he knows they were in the wrong.  He bears no ill will to the player and doesn't have time to truly mourn while his mission is still ongoing

317.speaker: Player
317.text: I've explained all that I'm going to. Accept that or I'll give you the same treatment they got.

64.speaker: Halsin
64.text: You rabid dog. Murderer! Those were the servants of Silvanus - nature's guardians!
64.context: NodeContext: Incandescent with anger. Can hardly believe what he's hearing.

103.speaker: Halsin
103.text: You will not see another day.
103.context: NodeContext: A cold, furious hiss. Combat breaks out immediately afterwards.

109.speaker: Player
109.text: It's who I am, who my mind makes me: a killer.

104.speaker: Halsin
104.text: And you... the way you speak... you're worse than the Absolutists here. At least they live with the pretence of purpose.

272.speaker: Player
272.text: Kagha carried out the Rite of Thorns - the grove has been sealed off from the world.

291.speaker: Halsin
291.context: NodeContext: Numb with shock. A catastrophe for Halsin - his home and sacred place of worship is basically lost to him forever.

23.speaker: Halsin
23.text: The grove is lost to me. To everyone. It's useless for me to stay here... there's nothing left to fight for.
23.context: NodeContext: The fight goes out of him.

253.speaker: Halsin
253.text: I will find you at your camp, and help you with your problem. Right now, I... I need to go be alone.
253.context: InternalNodeContext: Halsin to go off stage and reappear at the player camp. (New flag needed)NodeContext: Halsin leaves after this to process what's happened. He'll later reappear at the player's campsite.

235.speaker: Halsin
235.text: If you should have a chance to strike down the leaders of this horde, the world will be a better place for it. Farewell.
235.context: InternalNodeContext: Halsin to go off stage and reappear at the player camp. (New flag needed)NodeContext: Halsin leaves after this to process what's happened. He'll later reappear at the player's campsite.

22.speaker: Player
22.text: Altered parasites? A cure at Moonrise Towers, maybe? Sounds like guesswork at best.

82.speaker: Halsin
82.text: I'm as certain as I can be. If you have a better alternative, I won't stop you.

262.speaker: Halsin
262.text: I will help however I can. Let me see to some matters, then I will join you at your camp.

197.speaker: Halsin
197.text: Not that I'm eager to try stopping you, given the short work you made of the leadership here. With them dead, it's high time I got back to the grove.

42.speaker: Halsin
42.text: I can't stop you, in fact. Which brings me to my next problem...
42.context: NodeContext: Some hesitance in the second sentence. He's about to segue into asking a favour

281.speaker: Player
281.text: At least I know what to do now. Thank you.

249.speaker: Halsin
249.text: Wait. Now that the goblins' leaders are dead, I could join you - help you find a cure. I just need to make arrangements back at the grove. Find me there, if you wish.

108.speaker: Halsin
108.text: Wait - I could help you find a cure... but I need to settle matters here first.

265.speaker: Player
265.text: This magic isn't typical of how mind flayers procreate?

200.speaker: Halsin
200.text: No, this is different. Altered. The magic used is beyond me... it's either not of this world, or so ancient as to be lost to even nature's memory.

59.speaker: Player
59.text: So all of this was for nothing.

314.speaker: Halsin
314.text: Patience. I can't just snap my fingers... but I know where the solution almost certainly lies.

171.speaker: Player
171.text: You learned all this from your studies?

216.speaker: Halsin
216.text: Indeed. After we dealt with the drow that ambushed us, Nettie and I were able to inspect the corpse - and the creature that slithered out of it.

100.speaker: Player
100.text: How did you come to study mind flayer parasites?

5.speaker: Halsin
5.text: A drow forced me to defend myself. Afterwards, I was able to study the parasite that slithered out of the corpse, see what drives these 'True Souls'.

140.speaker: Halsin
140.text: I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.

150.speaker: Player
150.text: Sympathies won't help me to survive.

29.speaker: Player
29.text: This magic you mentioned - it isn't normal for these parasites?

169.speaker: Player
169.text: Then everything we did here was hopeless.

305.speaker: Halsin
305.text: It's no coincidence that you found me here, I'll wager? You're after a cure for this parasite.

87.speaker: Player
87.text: The bear is a noble beast. I will not fear it, or abandon it.

184.speaker: Halsin
184.text: A jest - I truly am grateful. If only I could repay you.

51.speaker: Player
51.text: You owe more than thanks, I think.

226.speaker: Halsin
226.text: Oh, certainly. But I live modestly at the best of times, and this is far from the best of times.
226.context: NodeContext: 'Do I look like I have any gold to pay you?'

311.speaker: Halsin
311.text: Perhaps there's something else I can offer you.

277.speaker: Halsin
277.text: Nature's blessings. I thought you'd be on your way by now... unless you changed your mind?

242.speaker: Player
242.text: I can't help you. I just need you to tell me about Moonrise Towers.
